new_src_summary:
In a reflective narrative, the author recounts their journey from Seattle to becoming a French horn player, despite dropping out of college at 19. Their unique path was supported by their parents, humorously referred to as a "gap decade," during which they traveled extensively, performed chamber music across the U.S. and Europe, and toured with a jazz guitarist before joining the Barcelona Symphony Orchestra. A pivotal moment occurred when the author noticed their mother's unusual silence at Christmas, leading to a conversation about her concerns for the author's lifestyle. This prompted the author to reflect into philosophical inquiries on political engagement, inspired by a childhood encounter with a National Geographic image of a young child in East Africa suffering from malnutrition. The image sparked a lifelong curiosity about the conditions of the world's's poorest and the factors influencing them.

Simultaneously, the author uncovers a significant yet under-appreciated fact that the percentage of the global population living in extreme poverty has decreased by 80% since the early 1970s, a remarkable achievement that most Americans are unaware of. Motivated by curiosity to understand the cause behind this improvement, the author seeks insights from mainstream economists across the political spectrum, focusing into the domain of economics with a specific focus on global poverty reduction. The primary factors contributing to this decrease include globalization, free trade, property rights, rule of law, and entrepreneurship, largely attributed to the spread of the free enterprise system globally post-1970. While acknowledging that free enterprise isn't flawless or the sole solution for building a better world, it has significant value and transcends political boundaries.

The author's main epiphany is that capitalism, at its best, embodies aspiration, which is a core element of the free enterprise system. The author believes this concept should be shared with more people. The second epiphany revolves around the notion that free markets have generated more wealth than any other system in history, lifting billions out of poverty. The speaker want to emphasize that this understanding could lead to progress both globally and domestically. The text employs a direct and informative writing style, focusing into presenting facts and ideas.

Regarding political motive asymmetry in America, the article discusses how Republicans and Democrats perceive their own ideology as driven by love or benevolence, while view the opposing side as motivated by hate. This asymmetry hinders societal progress. The author suggest acknowledging the real differences between ideologies without minimizing them, citing Jonathan Haidt, a psychology professor at NYU, who study the values and morals behind political ideologies. Liberals
new_tgt_summary:
Dans son texte, l'auteur partage son parcours personnel, commençant avec son enfance dans une famille respectée à Seattle, Washington. Inspiré par une image choc d un enfant africain pauvre publié dans le magazine National Geographic, il a choisi une voie différente en jouant de la musique de chambre et en travaillant avec un grand guitariste de jazz. Après avoir quitté l'université, il a rejoint l'Orchestre symphonique de Barcelone. Son engagement pour comprendre le déclin significatif de la pauvreté dans le monde depuis 1970 a conduit à une recherche politique indifférente à la tendance politique, se penchant sur les perspectives économiques traditionnelles. Il note que 80% de la population mondiale vivant sous le seuil de famine a diminué, une réalisation historique contre la pauvreté.

L'auteur a identifié cinq raisons principales pour lesquelles deux milliards de personnes ont réussi à sortir de la pauvreté : la mondialisation, le commerce international, les droits de propriété, le respect de la loi et l'entrepreneuriat, notamment l'émergence du système d'entreprise libre après 1970. Bien que ce système ne soit pas parfait, il a contribué à une grande amélioration économique. Il insiste sur le fait que le capitalisme est davantage qu une simple accumulation de richesses, il englobe l'aspiration et l'atteinte de rêves. 

En outre, l'auteur mentionne un événement organisé à l'Université Georgetown en mai 2015 où le président Barack Obama a souligné une opportunité pour résoudre le plus grand problème de l Amérique actuelle, impliquant une collaboration entre libéraux et conservateurs pour aider ceux qui en ont le plus besoin. Il fait également référence à une crise politique mondiale qui a atteint des niveaux critiques et qui est souvent alimentée par une asymmétrie de motivation politique. The author uncovers a significant yet under-appreciated fact that the percentage of the global population living in extreme poverty has decreased by 80% since the early 1970s, a remarkable achievement that most Americans are unaware of. The author seeks insights from mainstream economists across the political spectrum, focusing into the domain of economics with a specific focus on global poverty reduction. The primary factors contributing to this decrease include globalization, free trade, property rights, rule of law, and entrepreneurship, largely attributed to the spread of the free enterprise system globally post-1970. The author's main epiphany is that capitalism, at its best, embodies aspiration, which is a core element of the free enterprise system.
